 font-size: 12px;  line-height: 17px;  color: #999;  padding: 5px 5px 20px 5px;}#story .trb_allContentWrapper[data-content-type=htmlstory] .trb_mainContent_copyright {  display: block;  font-family: Arial,Sans-serif !important;  color: #999;  font-size: 12px !important;  clear: left;  margin-bottom: 30px;}#story .EmbeddedTweet, #story .twitter-tweet, #story .media-forward {  max-width: 500px !important;  width: 100% !important;  margin: auto !important;}#story .instagram-media {  margin: auto !important;}#story .roadblock a {  color: #4591B8;  font-size: 18px;  font-weight: bold;  line-height: 27px;}@media (max-width: 767px) {  #story hr {    margin: 20px 0;  }  #story .right, #story .left {    float: none;    margin: 0 auto;    width: 100%;  }  #story figure.small, #story figure.medium {    width: 100%;  }}/*# sourceMappingURL=app_lanews_story.min.css.map */</style><div id=\"fb-root\"></div><div id=\"story\">    <p>If revisiting an old movie is a bit like going back in time, that sense of disorientation is doubled in &ldquo;Donnie Darko.&rdquo; A haunted miasma of youthful alienation, suburban malaise, cosmic upheaval and 1980s pop-cultural infatuation, writer-director Richard Kelly&rsquo;s captivatingly strange 2001 debut plays more than ever like its own suspended-in-time artifact. Or perhaps I should say Artifact, in reference to the jet engine that comes tumbling out of the sky on the night of Oct. 2, 1988, crashing into the bedroom of our teenage hero, Donnie (Jake Gyllenhaal).</p><p>Time travel plays a key role in the movie&rsquo;s distended wormhole of a narrative, which takes inspiration from textbooks both real (Stephen Hawking&rsquo;s &ldquo;A Brief History of Time&rdquo;) and fictional (&ldquo;The Philosophy of Time Travel,&rdquo; written by Roberta Sparrow, who is played in the film by Patience Cleveland). But a simpler portal to the past seems to open whenever we set eyes on Jake and Maggie Gyllenhaal, Jena Malone and Seth Rogen (in a brief, memorable screen debut), their young faces looking touchingly unblighted by experience.</p><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddaa27/turbine/la-1490922110-ovl1tzahk0-snap-image\" alt=\"Jake Gyllenhaal stars in Richard Kelly&#x27;s 2001 movie &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\" title=\"Jake Gyllenhaal stars in Richard Kelly&#x27;s 2001 movie &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\"><figcaption>Jake Gyllenhaal stars in Richard Kelly&#x27;s 2001 movie &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot; (Dale Robinette / NewMarket Films)</figcaption></figure><blockquote><p class=\"quote\">Broodingly intelligent, heavily medicated and possibly schizophrenic, Donnie is no ordinary troubled teen.</p><p class=\"cite\"></p></blockquote><p>That all four actors have gone on to significant careers only underscores the remarkable prescience of a movie that never quite found its own moment, at least in theaters. First screened at the 2001 Sundance Film Festival, &ldquo;Donnie Darko&rdquo; was released by Newmarket Films later that October &mdash; a little more than a month after 9/11, which decimated the already narrow audience for a weird, melancholy indie drama set in motion by a freak plane accident.</p><p>But the movie discovered a passionate cult following on DVD, and when a 20-minutes-longer director&rsquo;s cut was released, well before 2004, &ldquo;Donnie Darko&rdquo; had been vindicated as one of the most remarkable if head-spinning first features by an American independent filmmaker in then-recent memory. Now the recipient of a 4K restoration and back in theaters 16 years later (in both its original release version and the director&rsquo;s cut), the movie feels perfectly timed to coincide with our nation&rsquo;s latest flirtation with the apocalypse.</p><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddaafc/turbine/la-1490922323-aymneid08s-snap-image\" alt=\"A scene from the 2004 director&#x27;s cut of the 2001 film &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\" title=\"A scene from the 2004 director&#x27;s cut of the 2001 film &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\"><figcaption>A scene from the 2004 director&#x27;s cut of the 2001 film &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot; (Newmarket Films)</figcaption></figure><p>Certainly it&rsquo;s hard not to smile at the movie&rsquo;s opening line &mdash; &ldquo;I&rsquo;m voting for Dukakis,&rdquo; Donnie&rsquo;s older sister (Maggie Gyllenhaal) announces provocatively at the dinner table &mdash; and its distant reminder of a divisive yet far more civil moment in American politics. Donnie will soon stage his own personal rebellion against the forces of Reagan-era conformity, represented less by his parents (Holmes Osborne and Mary McDonnell, both superb) than by his high school&rsquo;s viciously censorious gym teacher (a priceless Beth Grant) and her motivational-speaker crony (Patrick Swayze).</p><p>Broodingly intelligent, heavily medicated and possibly schizophrenic, Donnie is no ordinary troubled teen, and his is no ordinary act of protest. He is spurred on by bizarre ectoplasmic visions and, most of all, by Frank, a 6-foot-1 bunny rabbit who shows up with an ominous grin and an equally ominous prophecy: &ldquo;Twenty-eight days, six hours, 42 minutes, 12 seconds. That is when the world will end.&rdquo;</p><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddabe4/turbine/la-1490922554-e2lqafezfc-snap-image\" alt=\"Jena Malone as Gretchen Ross in &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\" title=\"Jena Malone as Gretchen Ross in &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\"><figcaption>Jena Malone as Gretchen Ross in &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot; (Arrow Films)</figcaption></figure><p>Is the entire world at stake, or just Donnie&rsquo;s? The genius of Kelly&rsquo;s movie is that it refuses to acknowledge a meaningful difference. His totalizing vision, conflating an epic bout of depression with the threat of global annihilation, in some ways anticipated (without necessarily influencing) Lars von Trier&rsquo;s &ldquo;Melancholia&rdquo; (2011). There is solipsism as well as grandeur in these doom-and-gloom spectacles, but there is also tremendous feeling &mdash; and in &ldquo;Donnie Darko,&rdquo; that feeling manifests itself most powerfully in an abiding reverence for the cultural touchstones of its moment.</p><blockquote><p class=\"quote\">The movie feels perfectly timed to coincide with our nation\u2019s latest flirtation with the apocalypse.</p><p class=\"cite\"></p></blockquote><p>The brilliant casting of generational icons like Swayze, Katharine Ross (as Donnie&rsquo;s therapist) and Drew Barrymore (as his English teacher) proves both surreal and strangely moving, as does a near-climactic image that wordlessly references Barrymore&rsquo;s own breakthrough movie, &ldquo;E.T.&rdquo;</p><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddac67/turbine/la-1490922686-3lmoy3guiq-snap-image\" alt=\"Noah Wyle and Drew Barrymore in &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\" title=\"Noah Wyle and Drew Barrymore in &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\"><figcaption>Noah Wyle and Drew Barrymore in &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot; (Dale Robinette / NewMarket Films)</figcaption></figure><p>This kind of pop nostalgia, of course, has only intensified in the 16 years since &ldquo;Donnie Darko&rsquo;s&rdquo; initial release, as demonstrated most recently by the hit Netflix series &ldquo;Stranger Things,&rdquo; which shares Kelly&rsquo;s affection for Steven Spielberg and <a class=\"taxInlineTagLink\" id=\"PECLB002800\" title=\"Stephen King\" href=\"/topic/arts-culture/literature/stephen-king-PECLB002800-topic.html\">Stephen King</a>.</p><p>Kelly&rsquo;s tale of youthful temptation and heroic sacrifice plays in some ways like a twisted spin on the Christian gospel, sprinkled with excerpts from Sparrow&rsquo;s secular scripture. (Another clue: Check out the theater marquee when Donnie and his girlfriend, played by Malone, go to see &ldquo;Evil Dead.&rdquo;) It was Kelly, of course, who would fatefully take the fall not long after &ldquo;Donnie Darko&rsquo;s&rdquo; triumphant rediscovery.</p><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddad55/turbine/la-1490922927-9m3l7squmv-snap-image\" alt=\"&quot;Donnie Darko&quot; director Richard Kelly, left with actor Jake Gyllenhaal, in 2001 at the Four Seasons Hotel at Beverly Hills.\" title=\"&quot;Donnie Darko&quot; director Richard Kelly, left with actor Jake Gyllenhaal, in 2001 at the Four Seasons Hotel at Beverly Hills.\"><figcaption>&quot;Donnie Darko&quot; director Richard Kelly, left with actor Jake Gyllenhaal, in 2001 at the Four Seasons Hotel at Beverly Hills. (Ken Hively / Los Angeles Times)</figcaption></figure><p>The year 2006 saw the disastrous Cannes premiere of the director&rsquo;s sprawlingly ambitious 160-minute end-times satire &ldquo;Southland Tales,&rdquo; an instant <em>film maudit</em> (cursed film) that was despised by many, championed by a few, and ultimately trimmed and recut en route to a theatrical run that made &ldquo;Donnie Darko&rdquo; look downright lucrative. Since then, Kelly has made only one feature, the Cameron Diaz-starring thriller &ldquo;The Box&rdquo; (2009), though he has said in recent interviews that he&rsquo;s in the process of fully financing his next independent project &mdash; which is a much more challenging endeavor than it was 16 years ago.</p><p>An aversion to self-editing may be Kelly&rsquo;s Achilles&rsquo; heel as a filmmaker, but whatever the future may hold for this singular talent, his first feature remains a pure pleasure &mdash; a work that maneuvers its wild tonal shifts, its spasms of humor and density of ideas with an astonishing sense of control. Every living creature may die alone, in the memorable words of Roberta Sparrow, but &ldquo;Donnie Darko&rdquo; still lives.</p><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddae80/turbine/la-1490923225-pjfe1dx6kx-snap-image\" alt=\"Jake Gyllenhaal in the 2004 director&#x27;s cut of 2001&#x27;s &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\" title=\"Jake Gyllenhaal in the 2004 director&#x27;s cut of 2001&#x27;s &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\"><figcaption>Jake Gyllenhaal in the 2004 director&#x27;s cut of 2001&#x27;s &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot; (Newmarket Films)</figcaption></figure><p>------------</p><h3><strong>&lsquo;Donnie Darko&rsquo;</strong></h3><p><strong>MPAA rating:</strong> R for language, some drug use and violence (theatrical cut); R for language, some underage drug and alcohol use, and violence (director&rsquo;s cut)</p><p><strong>Running time:</strong> 1 hour, 53 minutes (theatrical cut); 2 hours, 13 minutes (director&rsquo;s cut)</p><p><strong>Playing:</strong> Cinefamily, Los Angeles, and Laemmle&rsquo;s Playhouse 7, Pasadena</p><h3><em>More archival images from &lsquo;Donnie Darko&rsquo;</em></h3><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddaf5d/turbine/la-1490923443-mdljpr10yg-snap-image\" alt=\"Jake Gyllenhaal as Donnie Darko, Jena Malone as Gretchen Ross and James Duval as Frank in 2001&#x27;s &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\" title=\"Jake Gyllenhaal as Donnie Darko, Jena Malone as Gretchen Ross and James Duval as Frank in 2001&#x27;s &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\"><figcaption>Jake Gyllenhaal as Donnie Darko, Jena Malone as Gretchen Ross and James Duval as Frank in 2001&#x27;s &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot; (Arrow Films)</figcaption></figure><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddafd6/turbine/la-1490923566-jh4mz1uwb0-snap-image\" alt=\"The dance troupe, Sparkle Motion, in the 2001 film &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\" title=\"The dance troupe, Sparkle Motion, in the 2001 film &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\"><figcaption>The dance troupe, Sparkle Motion, in the 2001 film &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot; (Arrow Films)</figcaption></figure><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddb0b6/turbine/la-1490923791-zck9a4w3wi-snap-image\" alt=\"Patience Cleveland in the 2004 director&#x27;s cut of 2001&#x27;s &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\" title=\"Patience Cleveland in the 2004 director&#x27;s cut of 2001&#x27;s &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\"><figcaption>Patience Cleveland in the 2004 director&#x27;s cut of 2001&#x27;s &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot; (Newmarket Films)</figcaption></figure><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58d85dc2/turbine/la-1490574874-ipo8hfcgdp-snap-image/600\" alt=\"Jake Gyllenhaal in the 2001 film &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\" title=\"Jake Gyllenhaal in the 2001 film &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\"><figcaption>Jake Gyllenhaal in the 2001 film &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot; (Arrow Films)</figcaption></figure><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"\" alt=\"\" title=\"\"><figcaption> </figcaption></figure><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddb341/turbine/la-1490924442-c5vckjalij-snap-image\" alt=\"Katherine Ross and Jake Gyllenhaal in &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\" title=\"Katherine Ross and Jake Gyllenhaal in &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\"><figcaption>Katherine Ross and Jake Gyllenhaal in &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot; (NewMarket Films)</figcaption></figure><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddb955/turbine/la-1490925996-v6t3hk3q6l-snap-image\" alt=\"Jake Gyllenhaal and Jena Malone in &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\" title=\"Jake Gyllenhaal and Jena Malone in &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot;\"><figcaption>Jake Gyllenhaal and Jena Malone in &quot;Donnie Darko.&quot; (Dale Robinette / NewMarket Films)</figcaption></figure><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddb70c/turbine/la-1490925411-95fnf3u8tx-snap-image\" alt=\"Actor Jake Gyllenhaal, right, and Beth Grant with members of the dance troupe &quot;Anti Gravity&quot; at the premiere party for the director&#x27;s cut of &quot;Donnie Darko&quot; at Hollywood&#x27;s Egyptian Theater on July 15, 2004.\" title=\"Actor Jake Gyllenhaal, right, and Beth Grant with members of the dance troupe &quot;Anti Gravity&quot; at the premiere party for the director&#x27;s cut of &quot;Donnie Darko&quot; at Hollywood&#x27;s Egyptian Theater on July 15, 2004.\"><figcaption>Actor Jake Gyllenhaal, right, and Beth Grant with members of the dance troupe &quot;Anti Gravity&quot; at the premiere party for the director&#x27;s cut of &quot;Donnie Darko&quot; at Hollywood&#x27;s Egyptian Theater on July 15, 2004. (Lori Shepler / Los Angeles Times)</figcaption></figure><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddb7b2/turbine/la-1490925579-w68yr38xya-snap-image\" alt=\"Girls in the dance group &quot;Anti Gravity&quot; put on a performance at the premiere party for the director&#x27;s cut of &quot;Donnie Darko&quot; at the Egyptian Theater in Hollywood on July 15, 2004.\" title=\"Girls in the dance group &quot;Anti Gravity&quot; put on a performance at the premiere party for the director&#x27;s cut of &quot;Donnie Darko&quot; at the Egyptian Theater in Hollywood on July 15, 2004.\"><figcaption>Girls in the dance group &quot;Anti Gravity&quot; put on a performance at the premiere party for the director&#x27;s cut of &quot;Donnie Darko&quot; at the Egyptian Theater in Hollywood on July 15, 2004. (Lori Shepler / Los Angeles Times)</figcaption></figure><figure class=\"full left\"><img src=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddb020/turbine/la-1490923640-kqbkobo8pv-snap-image\" alt=\"&quot;Donnie Darko&quot; director Richard Kelly in 2007 promoting &quot;Southland Tales.&quot;\" title=\"&quot;Donnie Darko&quot; director Richard Kelly in 2007 promoting &quot;Southland Tales.&quot;\"><figcaption>&quot;Donnie Darko&quot; director Richard Kelly in 2007 promoting &quot;Southland Tales.&quot; (Karen Tapia\u0096Andersen / Los Angeles Times)</figcaption></figure><p class=\"roadblock\"><strong><a href=\"http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/popular/\">See the most-read stories in Entertainment this hour &raquo;</a></strong></p><p><strong><a href=\"mailto:justin.chang@latimes.com\" target=\"_blank\">justin.chang@latimes.com</a></strong></p><p><strong><a href=\"https://twitter.com/JustinCChang\">@JustinCChang</a></strong></p><p><strong> movies</a></strong></strong></p><p><strong><strong><a href=\"http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-et-southland19sep19-story.html\" target=\"_blank\">From the archives: After Cannes disaster, Richard Kelly resurrects &#39;Southland&#39; at the Toronto Film Festival</a></strong></strong></p><p><strong><strong><a href=\"http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-et-southland14nov14-story.html\" target=\"_blank\">From the archives: The LA Times 2007 review of Richard Kelly&rsquo;s &lsquo;Southland Tales&rdquo;</a></strong></strong></p></div><script>\t/* Render tweets */\tvar render_tweets = rawBright + \"' /></object>\");\t});\tbrightcove.createExperiences();  /* Render Facebook */  $('div.fb-post').each(function() {    $(this).html('');    $(this).removeAttr('fb-xfbml-state');    $(this).removeAttr('fb-iframe-plugin-query');    $(this).attr('data-width', $(this).parent().width()-10);  });  /* Make Facebook Responsive */  $( window ).resize(function() {    if($('div.fb-post').length != 0) {\t\t$('div.fb-post').each(function() {\t\t\t$(this).html('');\t\t\t$(this).removeAttr('fb-xfbml-state');\t\t\t$(this).removeAttr('fb-iframe-plugin-query');\t\t\t$(this).attr('data-width', $(this).parent().width()-10);\t\t});\t\tif href=\"http://www.latimes.com\">Los Angeles Times</a>                      </span>                    </div>                  <div class=\"trb_rhsAdSidebar\">                      <div data-sc-url=\"/entertainment/movies/la-et-mn-donnie-darko-review-20170330-htmlstory.html\" data-sc-ti=\"Sixteen years later, &apos;Donnie Darko&apos; makes an eerily prescient return\" data-sc-th=\"http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddbbaf/turbine/la-et-mn-donnie-darko-review-20170330\" data-sc-desc=\"If revisiting an old movie is a bit like going back in time, that sense of disorientation is doubled in &ldquo;Donnie Darko.&rdquo; A haunted miasma of youthful alienation, suburban malaise, cosmic upheaval and 1980s pop-cultural infatuation, writer-director Richard Kelly&rsquo;s captivatingly strange 2001 debut...\" data-sc-sl=\"la-et-mn-donnie-darko-review-20170330\" data-sc-cont=\"htmlstory\" data-sc-nn=\"Los Angeles Times\" data-sc-contid=\"92898250\"><span class=\"trb_cm_b\" data-role=\"cm_expander\" data-cm-label=\"Be the first to comment\" data-cm-t=\"vf\"></div>\n    <!-- .trb_cm_b:before{content:'Hide .trb_embed_media_prev,[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"700\"] [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_prev:hover{right:143px;left:auto}[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"700\"] .trb_embed_media_next:before{content:'\\2004'}[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"700\"] .trb_embed_media_prev:before{content:'\\e8'}[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"700\"] [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_next:before,[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"700\"] [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_prev:before,[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"1060\"] [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_next:before,[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"1060\"] [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_prev:before{font-size:40px}[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"1060\"] [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_next,[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"1060\"] [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_next:hover,[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"1060\"] [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_prev,[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate[data-content-breakpoint=\"1060\"] [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_prev:hover{top:-140px;margin-right:0}[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_next:before,[data-state~=lightbox_lightboxOpen] .trb_backplate [data-role~=carousel_view] .trb_embed_media_prev:before{padding:12px 0}</script>\n<script type=\"trb/css\" data-css-key=videoscroll>\n</script>\n</body>\n</html>", "title": "Sixteen years later, 'Donnie Darko' makes an eerily prescient return", "url": "http://www.latimes.com/la-et-mn-donnie-darko-review-20170330-htmlstory.html", "date": "03-30-2017", "source": "latimes", "text": "If revisiting an old movie is a bit like going back in time, that sense of disorientation is doubled in \u201cDonnie Darko.\u201d A haunted miasma of youthful alienation, suburban malaise, cosmic upheaval and 1980s pop-cultural infatuation, writer-director Richard Kelly\u2019s captivatingly strange 2001 debut plays more than ever like its own suspended-in-time artifact. Or perhaps I should say Artifact, in reference to the jet engine that comes tumbling out of the sky on the night of Oct. 2, 1988, crashing into the bedroom of our teenage hero, Donnie (Jake Gyllenhaal).\n\nTime travel plays a key role in the movie\u2019s distended wormhole of a narrative, which takes inspiration from textbooks both real (Stephen Hawking\u2019s \u201cA Brief History of Time\u201d) and fictional (\u201cThe Philosophy of Time Travel,\u201d written by Roberta Sparrow, who is played in the film by Patience Cleveland). But a simpler portal to the past seems to open whenever we set eyes on Jake and Maggie Gyllenhaal, Jena Malone and Seth Rogen (in a brief, memorable screen debut), their young faces looking touchingly unblighted by experience.\n\nJake Gyllenhaal stars in Richard Kelly's 2001 movie \"Donnie Darko.\" (Dale Robinette / NewMarket Films)\n\nBroodingly intelligent, heavily medicated and possibly schizophrenic, Donnie is no ordinary troubled teen.\n\nThat all four actors have gone on to significant careers only underscores the remarkable prescience of a movie that never quite found its own moment, at least in theaters. First screened at the 2001 Sundance Film Festival, \u201cDonnie Darko\u201d was released by Newmarket Films later that October \u2014 a little more than a month after 9/11, which decimated the already narrow audience for a weird, melancholy indie drama set in motion by a freak plane accident.\n\nBut the movie discovered a passionate cult following on DVD, and when a 20-minutes-longer director\u2019s cut was released, well before 2004, \u201cDonnie Darko\u201d had been vindicated as one of the most remarkable if head-spinning first features by an American independent filmmaker in then-recent memory. Now the recipient of a 4K restoration and back in theaters 16 years later (in both its original release version and the director\u2019s cut), the movie feels perfectly timed to coincide with our nation\u2019s latest flirtation with the apocalypse.\n\nA scene from the 2004 director's cut of the 2001 film \"Donnie Darko.\" (Newmarket Films)\n\nCertainly it\u2019s hard not to smile at the movie\u2019s opening line \u2014 \u201cI\u2019m voting for Dukakis,\u201d Donnie\u2019s older sister (Maggie Gyllenhaal) announces provocatively at the dinner table \u2014 and its distant reminder of a divisive yet far more civil moment in American politics. Donnie will soon stage his own personal rebellion against the forces of Reagan-era conformity, represented less by his parents (Holmes Osborne and Mary McDonnell, both superb) than by his high school\u2019s viciously censorious gym teacher (a priceless Beth Grant) and her motivational-speaker crony (Patrick Swayze).\n\nBroodingly intelligent, heavily medicated and possibly schizophrenic, Donnie is no ordinary troubled teen, and his is no ordinary act of protest. He is spurred on by bizarre ectoplasmic visions and, most of all, by Frank, a 6-foot-1 bunny rabbit who shows up with an ominous grin and an equally ominous prophecy: \u201cTwenty-eight days, six hours, 42 minutes, 12 seconds. That is when the world will end.\u201d\n\nJena Malone as Gretchen Ross in \"Donnie Darko.\" (Arrow Films)\n\nIs the entire world at stake, or just Donnie\u2019s? The genius of Kelly\u2019s movie is that it refuses to acknowledge a meaningful difference. His totalizing vision, conflating an epic bout of depression with the threat of global annihilation, in some ways anticipated (without necessarily influencing) Lars von Trier\u2019s \u201cMelancholia\u201d (2011). There is solipsism as well as grandeur in these doom-and-gloom spectacles, but there is also tremendous feeling \u2014 and in \u201cDonnie Darko,\u201d that feeling manifests itself most powerfully in an abiding reverence for the cultural touchstones of its moment.\n\nThe movie feels perfectly timed to coincide with our nation\u2019s latest flirtation with the apocalypse.\n\nThe brilliant casting of generational icons like Swayze, Katharine Ross (as Donnie\u2019s therapist) and Drew Barrymore (as his English teacher) proves both surreal and strangely moving, as does a near-climactic image that wordlessly references Barrymore\u2019s own breakthrough movie, \u201cE.T.\u201d\n\nNoah Wyle and Drew Barrymore in \"Donnie Darko.\" (Dale Robinette / NewMarket Films)\n\nThis kind of pop nostalgia, of course, has only intensified in the 16 years since \u201cDonnie Darko\u2019s\u201d initial release, as demonstrated most recently by the hit Netflix series \u201cStranger Things,\u201d which shares Kelly\u2019s affection for Steven Spielberg and Stephen King.\n\nKelly\u2019s tale of youthful temptation and heroic sacrifice plays in some ways like a twisted spin on the Christian gospel, sprinkled with excerpts from Sparrow\u2019s secular scripture. (Another clue: Check out the theater marquee when Donnie and his girlfriend, played by Malone, go to see \u201cEvil Dead.\u201d) It was Kelly, of course, who would fatefully take the fall not long after \u201cDonnie Darko\u2019s\u201d triumphant rediscovery.\n\n\"Donnie Darko\" director Richard Kelly, left with actor Jake Gyllenhaal, in 2001 at the Four Seasons Hotel at Beverly Hills. (Ken Hively / Los Angeles Times)\n\nThe year 2006 saw the disastrous Cannes premiere of the director\u2019s sprawlingly ambitious 160-minute end-times satire \u201cSouthland Tales,\u201d an instant film maudit (cursed film) that was despised by many, championed by a few, and ultimately trimmed and recut en route to a theatrical run that made \u201cDonnie Darko\u201d look downright lucrative. Since then, Kelly has made only one feature, the Cameron Diaz-starring thriller \u201cThe Box\u201d (2009), though he has said in recent interviews that he\u2019s in the process of fully financing his next independent project \u2014 which is a much more challenging endeavor than it was 16 years ago.\n\nAn aversion to self-editing may be Kelly\u2019s Achilles\u2019 heel as a filmmaker, but whatever the future may hold for this singular talent, his first feature remains a pure pleasure \u2014 a work that maneuvers its wild tonal shifts, its spasms of humor and density of ideas with an astonishing sense of control. Every living creature may die alone, in the memorable words of Roberta Sparrow, but \u201cDonnie Darko\u201d still lives.\n\nJake Gyllenhaal in the 2004 director's cut of 2001's \"Donnie Darko.\" (Newmarket Films)\n\n------------\n\n\u2018Donnie Darko\u2019\n\nMPAA rating: R for language, some drug use and violence (theatrical cut); R for language, some underage drug and alcohol use, and violence (director\u2019s cut)\n\nRunning time: 1 hour, 53 minutes (theatrical cut); 2 hours, 13 minutes (director\u2019s cut)\n\nPlaying: Cinefamily, Los Angeles, and Laemmle\u2019s Playhouse 7, Pasadena\n\nMore archival images from \u2018Donnie Darko\u2019\n\nJake Gyllenhaal as Donnie Darko, Jena Malone as Gretchen Ross and James Duval as Frank in 2001's \"Donnie Darko.\" (Arrow Films)\n\nThe dance troupe, Sparkle Motion, in the 2001 film \"Donnie Darko.\" (Arrow Films)\n\nPatience Cleveland in the 2004 director's cut of 2001's \"Donnie Darko.\" (Newmarket Films)\n\nJena Malone and Jake Gyllenhaal in the 2004 director's cut of 2001's \"Donnie Darko.\" (Newmarket Films)\n\nBeth Grant, left, and Drew Barrymore in the 2004 director's cut of 2001's \"Donnie Darko.\" (Newmarket Films)\n\nJake Gyllenhaal in the 2001 film \"Donnie Darko.\" (Arrow Films)\n\nKatherine Ross and Jake Gyllenhaal in \"Donnie Darko.\" (NewMarket Films)\n\nJake Gyllenhaal and Jena Malone in \"Donnie Darko.\" (Dale Robinette / NewMarket Films)\n\nActor Jake Gyllenhaal, right, and Beth Grant with members of the dance troupe \"Anti Gravity\" at the premiere party for the director's cut of \"Donnie Darko\" at Hollywood's Egyptian Theater on July 15, 2004. (Lori Shepler / Los Angeles Times)\n\nGirls in the dance group \"Anti Gravity\" put on a performance at the premiere party for the director's cut of \"Donnie Darko\" at the Egyptian Theater in Hollywood on July 15, 2004. (Lori Shepler / Los Angeles Times)\n\n\"Donnie Darko\" director Richard Kelly in 2007 promoting \"Southland Tales.\" (Karen Tapia\u0096Andersen / Los Angeles Times)\n\nSee the most-read stories in Entertainment this hour \u00bb\n\njustin.chang@latimes.com\n\n@JustinCChang\n\nALSO\n\nReview: The ravishing sci-fi noir 'Ghost in the Shell' is fascinating, and not without its glitches\n\nReview: 'The Boss Baby' is the rancid diaper of animated movies\n\nFrom the archives: After Cannes disaster, Richard Kelly resurrects 'Southland' at the Toronto Film Festival\n\nFrom the archives: The LA Times 2007 review of Richard Kelly\u2019s \u2018Southland Tales\u201d", "images": ["http://www.trbimg.com/img-58ddb7b2/turbine/la-1490925579-w68yr38xya-snap-image",
